Here’s the way I see it

Yes climate change is a problem

But seeing how we haven’t all died yet it’s not as dire as people claim it is

What I think the bigger problem facing our planet will be is we’re gonna run out of oil so we’re gonna have to find alternatives to gasoline

I’ve heard propane emits less C02 than gas and can be produced renewably using E. coli bacteria

So if you want a cleaner automotive fuel that’ll last forever there’s one alternative

The only downside is it requires a big tank but who wants a compact car anyway

Propane cars aside yes I think climate change is a problem but that’s something we can and we are dealing with

A bigger problem in my opinion is the world will in laments terms run out of gas

I do want to point out that while living in a wealthy country increases your carbon footprint, living in a city decreases it. The decrease for living in a city is about 30%, so it doesn't make up for the 90% increase for living in a rich country, but it does help. If you combine that with responsible envoronmental policy in the long term, it can be brought down to a safe and sustainable level... eventually.

But the biggest environmental problem in there was the beef. Hopefully lab grown meat will eventually solve that problem because people are not going to go vegan in nearly enough numbers to solve it that way (myself included).

Good video, just living in a developed country means that you contribute vastly more to climate change than the average person in the world and need to be EXTREMELY conscious of what you do and buy in order to really be in a place to condescend to other people about it.  Even then you're probably having little effect.  Now, I think it's great for everyone, as a collective, to try and make small changes in the right direction as much as possible, but turning your nose up at a large portion of the population and labeling them as "deniers" first of all makes it sound like it's a god damn religion and also just really turns people off from wanting to make any change at all.  It's really not what science is all about; this isn't politics and we should all be in this together.

I really like the message in this, and I feel a similar ideology can be applied to veganism. If it's hard to make the jump, build a bridge. You could start off with just being more conscious of how much meat you're eating, and then maybe trying one meal every day without meat, or two, or half the week without meat, or you could try not buying any meat at home, but on special occasions if you're out with friends or something, you can have some. Figure out what works for you, because all your little decisions add up, so don't get discouraged if you can't just cut it all out, trying a little is still better than not trying at all :)

Really good video but the emissions fact is weirldly skewed. Its only accounts for fossil fuel emissions but not the burning of wood to cook and keep warm in 3rd world countries. If you take that into context than 3rd world countries contribute more to C02 emissions than many 1st world countries including the US and Canada

Barking up the wrong tree, reduction is not a feesable remedy to climate change. Our use of concrete as a building material alone necessitates the release of geologically stored carbon in excess of what the environment can react to to prevent accumulation. And it simply cannot be replaced. The only way we could concievably prevent global warming is by tackling the problem from the other side. Accelerate the natural processes that sequester carbon in the lithosphere or reduce the incoming solar radiation. Of the two the first is the preferable alternative as the byproduct would be increased ocean biodensity, which would help feed our growing population.
